pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->
- [x] depends on: #22290

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [b5fc2fbbe3](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/22039/commits/b5fc2fbbe3620492f31eb9d036891c0461ce5e29)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Tactic | 2585 | 2589 | +4 (+0.15%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Tactic`|4|
| `Mathlib.Tactic.Simproc.FinsetInterval` (new file)|553|

</details>

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ evalFinsetIccNat`
`+ mkNatLitQ`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>Increase in tech debt: (relative, absolute) = (1.00, 0.00)</summary>

|Current number|Change|Type|
|-:|:-:|:-|
|1266|1|erw|

Current commit [b5fc2fbbe3](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/b5fc2fbbe3620492f31eb9d036891c0461ce5e29)
Reference commit [b4a4fd8e8b](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/b4a4fd8e8b5813e105339bb0a307182cf76be900)

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

@eric-wieser, I tried making this simproc as a prototypical example of a simproc (I doubt it is actually useful as a default simproc, would be nice if simprocs could be added to individual simp calls similarly to lemmas) but it times out any slightly non-trivial example. Could you explain what I did wrong?

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#22290~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

@eric-wieser, your suggested Qq-ification results in `unusedHavesSuffices` warnings which I can't seem to disable (`set_option linter.unusedHavesSuffices false in` doesn't work because `linter.unusedHavesSuffices` isn't an option)

> @eric-wieser, your suggested Qq-ification results in `unusedHavesSuffices` warnings which I can't seem to disable (`set_option linter.unusedHavesSuffices false in` doesn't work because `linter.unusedHavesSuffices` isn't an option)

Yes, you want `nolint` because this is an environment linter.
This generally looks close, please ping me or Mario for another round of review.

> would be nice if simprocs could be added to individual simp calls similarly to lemmas

I believe this makes it so the simproc isn't added to the global simpset and you can pass it as if it were a lemma.

```suggestion
simproc_decl finsetIcc_nat (Icc _ _) := fun e â†¦ do
```
ðŸ’¡

```suggestion
example : Icc 1 0 = âˆ… := by simp [finsetIcc_nat, -Icc_eq_empty_of_lt, -Icc_eq_empty_iff]
```
I think you'll want to add this for the proof the compile

I think I found the problem. The `eml` on recursive calls was of the form `q(Nat.succ _)`, which is not a natural literal. This caused `Expr.natLit!` to panic. We can solve this by only parsing `m` and `n` once at the start and keeping track of `m` on recursive calls.

```suggestion
partial def evalFinsetIccNat {em eml en enl : Q(â„•)} (m n : â„•) (hm : Q(IsNat $em $eml))
    (hn : Q(IsNat $en $enl)) : MetaM ((s : Q(Finset â„•)) Ã— Q(.Icc $em $en = $s)) := do
  if m â‰¤ n then
    let hmn â† mkDecideProofQq q($em â‰¤ $en)
    let hm' := q(isNat_natSucc $hm rfl)
    let âŸ¨s, hsâŸ© â† evalFinsetIccNat (m+1) n hm' hn
    return âŸ¨q(insert $em $s), q(Icc_eq_insert_of_Icc_succ_eq $hmn $hs)âŸ©
  else
    let hnm â† mkDecideProofQq q($en < $em)
    return âŸ¨q(âˆ…), q(Finset.Icc_eq_empty_of_lt $hnm)âŸ©

simproc_decl finsetIcc_nat (Icc _ _) := fun e â†¦ do
  let âŸ¨1, ~q(Finset â„•), ~q(Icc (OfNat.ofNat $em) (OfNat.ofNat $en))âŸ© â† inferTypeQ e
    | return .continue
  let hm : Q(IsNat (OfNat.ofNat $em) $em) := q(âŸ¨rflâŸ©)
  let hn : Q(IsNat (OfNat.ofNat $en) $en) := q(âŸ¨rflâŸ©)
  unless em.isRawNatLit && en.isRawNatLit do
    return .continue
  let m := em.natLit!
  let n := en.natLit!
  let âŸ¨s, pâŸ© â† evalFinsetIccNat m n hm hn
  return .done { expr := s, proof? := p }

example : Icc 1 0 = âˆ… := by simp [finsetIcc_nat, -Icc_eq_empty_of_lt, -Icc_eq_empty_iff]
example : Icc 1 1 = {1} := by simp [finsetIcc_nat, -Icc_self]
example : Icc 1 2 = {1, 2} := by simp [finsetIcc_nat]
```
I think the reason for the timeout here is that `natLit!` panics.

```suggestion
lemma Icc_succ_pred_eq_Ioo : Icc (a + 1) (b - 1) = Ioo a b := by
```
to distinguish from `Icc a b = Ioo (a - 1) (b + 1)` or similar.

```suggestion
simproc_decl Icc_ofNat_ofNat (Icc _ _) := fun e â†¦ do
```
since this is really about `ofNat` in an `Icc` term.
I'm not sure I am following. This does *not* compute `Icc (2 : Int) (4 : Int)` (I am letting @Paul-Lez write a similar simproc for that, which he'll call `Icc_int`)
I think you could justify logging a warning here, if this happens then something has gone wrong.
No need to `decide`, you can just use `Eq.refl` to get the equality of raw nat literals
How? `let hmn : Q($em = $en) := q(rfl)` rightfully complains

This should work:
```
have : $em =Q $en := \<\> 
```
then you don't even need to build the `rfl` proof and can remove it from your helper theorem.
Okay, I see. You're claiming that decide-eq numerals are actually defeq
Hot take: we should produce `Finset.cons` instead!
Maybe, but it doesn't have the nice notation associated with it. Beginners would certainly expect the nice notation to be produced
What about we instead have another simproc that turns any `insert` into `cons`? I guess that will be quadratic time in general ðŸ˜¬
Currently, we `simp`lify the other way around.
Yeah, I don't think that's great either
Perhaps worth a note that these are not in the default simp set because we don't want `Icc 0 (2 ^ 1024)` to explode under `simp`.
I have some code somewhere that Qq-ifies this to make things easier; I'll see if I can find it.
That would be great. It feels sad that Qq support ends at `NormNum.Result`
Can you add some tests of reversed bounds?
... as in `Icc a b` where `b < a`? Isn't the first one enough?
Here you could assert the defeq `$en =Q $en' + 1` (where `en' := mkRawNatLit n`) and then this would be true by a lemma application rather than a tactic.

You'll have to be more precise here: The following fails
```
    let en' := mkRawNatLitQq n
    haveI' : $en =Q $en' + 1 := âŸ¨âŸ©
    let hn := q(isNat_natPred $hn rfl)
    /-
    reduceEval: failed to evaluate argument
      n
    -/
```
Replacing the `let` with `have` should fix that.
Suggest naming `Mathlib.Tactic.Simproc.FinsetInterval`. Clearer, and more consistent with Lean.
Let's not introduce the neologism "synteq" unnecesarily. :-)
I like it ðŸ˜¢
Does it work (haven't tried!) to put `OfNat.ofNat` in the pattern, however?
My guess is no, since all the `no_index` stuff is about excluding `ofNat` from patterns.
Nope, doesn't work indeed

Something to consider: turn these on by default, but with a hard-coded (or option controlled?) limit on the size of the produced Finset. (Perhaps around 37? :-)

There's a trade-off between convenience, and someone getting confused about why it suddenly stops working when they use it above the limit.

I don't think it is ever convenient for these to be on by default? Happy to be outvoted here

+ I'm not sure how to get the default limit working without introducing two simprocs, one on by default which only works for small sizes, one off by default which works for all sizes

I think these are usually done with `hmn : Q(Nat.ble #em #en = true) := (q(Eq.refl true) :)` or similar.

Looking for `ble` should find them.
This is no longer used, but I'd be happy to merge it in another PR (if you also eliminated existing callers of `mkDecideProof`)
Will do
The convention is a single trailing `Q`.
Could you try to use `ofQ` here?
I would love to but it hasn't landed, right?
Ah, it `Simproc.ofQ`
Sadly, this makes my simprocs not follow the line of sight rule anymore ðŸ˜¦ Any way I can make sure the main branch of my simproc stays unindented?
Unfortunately not, but this is not really any different to the typical `| _ => throwUnsupportedSyntax` that appears elsewhere.

```suggestion
      return .done <| .mk _ q(Iio_zero)
```
etc
There are two of them which I didn't manage to make Qq-safe. Feel free to push suggestions

This pattern could perhaps become
```lean
def natCasesQ (en : Q(â„•)) {motive : Type}
  (zero : $en =Q 0 â†’ motive) (succ : âˆ€ (n : â„•) (en : Q(â„•)), $en =Q $n + 1 â†’ motive) :
    Option motive :=
  match en.rawNatLit? with
  | some 0 => zero âŸ¨âŸ©
  | some (n + 1) => succ n (mkNatLitQ n) âŸ¨âŸ©
  | none => none
```
but perhaps best left to a later PR.
These belong in a (standalone) test file.

I still don't understand the point of making standalone test files for things that already function the way they're intended to work by the end of their file:
1. Tests can already be made at the end of the file
2. One gets instantaneous feedback when modifying the thing/fixing breakage
3. The tests demonstrate to the wandering user how to use the thing
4. The tests don't weigh in the oleans + those specific ones are instantaneous
Can you make a Zulip thread making these points?

```suggestion
simproc_decl Icc_ofNat_ofNat (Icc _ _) := .ofQ fun u Î± e â†¦ do
```

pullRequest.title: feat: simproc for computing `Finset.Ixx` of natural numbers

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: Qq version of `mkDecideProof`

@eric-wieser, your suggested Qq-ification results in `unusedHavesSuffices` warnings which I can't seem to disable (`set_option linter.unusedHavesSuffices false in` doesn't work because `linter.unusedHavesSuffices` isn't an option)
